newsitem.title: USA: Man kills self in apparent cult suicide copycat.
newsitem.headline: Man kills self in apparent cult suicide copycat.

text.p: A 58-year-old recluse was found dead in his home in a remote mountain canyon in northern California in an apparent copycat of the mass suicide of Heaven's Gate cult members, police said on Tuesday.
A suicide note, found next to the body of Robert Nichols in his trailer home outside Marysville, read: "I'm going to the spaceship with Hale-Bopp to be with those who have gone before me."
The 39 members of the Heaven's Gate cult committed suicide in their rented million-dollar mansion in the exclusive San Diego, California, suburb of Rancho Santa Fe last week.
Videotaped suicide notes discovered along with their bodies last Wednesday showed the members believed an alien spaceship hiding behind the Hale-Bopp comet would transport them to heaven.
Yuba County Undersheriff Gary Finch said when Nichols' body was found on Sunday it was draped in a purple shroud similar to the shrouds covering the bodies of the Heaven's Gate cult members.
Nichols had a plastic bag over his head and had apparently died from gas poisoning by putting a hose from a propane tank into the bag, Finch said.

But Marysville resident Alison Mattorolo, whose husband Richard discovered Nichols' body, said she had known the dead man for a number of years and that he was "never a cult member and never even expressed any interest in cults."
"He was very much into astrology. He thought this comet was the second coming of Christ. It was a separate thing, nothing to do with cults," she told Reuters.

Mattorolo said Nichols had been a roadie for the Grateful Dead and had written a book on his experiences with the fabled rock group called "Truckin' With the Grateful Dead to Egypt." He had been in the process of writing a second book on the group, she added.

Mattorolo said Nichols' death shocked and upset her. "I never thought he would do anything like this. He has always been kind of trippy, like the flower children. He was a loner, but he was a happy-go-lucky sort."
